table.name: mem
table.column: behave as, act in the manner of

table.name: mem
table.column:
{SoH:n}:{ghaH:n}/{'oH:n}/{chaH:n}/{bIH:n} = {Da-:v:pref,nolink}
When used with {-lu':v}, this prefix means "Someone (indefinite subject) does something to you".

table.name: mem
table.column: In Klingon, when one lives at a place, he or she is thought of as occupying or inhabiting it. That is, he or she is not seen as doing something at a location, but rather as doing something to it.[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: "Ichabod Mudd" ({'IqbaD:sen:nolink}) was the name of a character on the Captain Midnight radio serial.

table.name: mem
table.column: Wenn du bedroht wirst, dann kämpfe.

table.name: mem
table.column: be not attentive, be distracted, lack focus
This applies to a person who is not focused on the task at hand.[1, p.149]

table.name: mem
table.column: I must wash my hair now.
Ich muss mir jetzt die Haare waschen.
This is something you might say to turn down someone's romantic overtures.

table.name: mem
table.column: This line was spoken in Klingon but was not subtitled.

table.name: mem
table.column:
While both {DaHjaj:n:nolink} and {jajvam:n} mean "today", they are not quite interchangeable. {DaHjaj:n:nolink} (but not {jajvam:n:nolink}) is used as the time element in a sentence: {DaHjaj romuluSngan vIHoHpu':sen:nolink} "today I killed a Romulan".[2]
As the subject of a sentence, {jajvam:n:nolink} is more typically found, though {DaHjaj:n:nolink} is not impossible. Compare: ▶ {nI' jajvam:sen:nolink} "this day is long" ▶ {nI' DaHjaj:sen:nolink} "today is long"[2]
{DaHjaj:n:nolink} also behaves as a noun in such noun-noun constructions as {DaHjaj gheD:n} "today's prey", a term often heard in Klingon restaurants with a meaning comparable to "catch of the day".[2]
{DaHjaj:n:nolink} is also used with words indicating a time of day to refer to that portion of the current day. For example, {DaHjaj ram:n}, literally "today's night", means "tonight".[2]
As a time element, {DaHjaj:n} precedes any adverbials.[1, sec. 6.7]

table.name: mem
table.column: dish in a restaurant, "catch of the day"

table.name: mem
table.column: May you die before you are captured.
Mögest du sterben bevor du gefangen genommen wirst.

table.name: mem
table.column: ▶ {chenmoHlu'meH Daq:n} ▶ {wej Daqmey yIHeD.:sen:nolink} "Go back three spaces."[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: This word has appeared only in a deleted scene from the 2009 {Star Trek:src} movie.

table.name: mem
table.column: Ich weiß nicht wo ich bin.

On {TKD p.172:src}, "I'm lost" is given as {jIHtaHbogh naDev vISovbe'.:sen:nolink} On {PK:src}, "I'm lost" is given in both regular and clipped Klingon versions, the latter of which is {DaqwIj Sovbe'.:sen:nolink}

table.name: mem
table.column:
In Klingon, this is a command rather than a question. It literally means, "Identify the place where you live!"[1]
An acceptable way to phrase this demand as a question is {nuq DaDab?:sen:nolink}[1]

table.name: mem
table.column:
To answer in the affirmative, say {luq:excl} "okay".
To answer in the negative, say {Qo':excl} "no, I refuse".

▶ {pa'lIjDaq qaDor.:sen:nolink} "I will escort you to your quarters." ▶ {tachDaq qaDor.:sen:nolink} "I will escort you to the bar." ▶ {vaS'a'Daq qaDor.:sen:nolink} "I will escort you to the Great Hall."

table.name: mem
table.column: There is an idiom, {jej; Daqtagh rur}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This refers to the beverage only. For the dried-up mixture used to brew tea, see {Qenvob:n}.
Darjeeling is a type of tea.
▶ {Hoch vor Dargh wIb.:sen:nolink} "Sour tea cures everything."[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: ▶ {Hoch vor Dargh wIb.:sen:nolink} "Sour tea cures everything."[1]

table.name: mem
table.column: In {TNK:src}, "cup and saucer" is translated as {Dargh HIvje' jengva' je:n@@Dargh HIvje':n, jengva':n, je:conj}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This refers to a line in "Lady Madonna" by The Beatles: "Monday's child has learned to tie his bootlace."

table.name: mem
table.column: This word is never followed by the locative suffix {-Daq:n:suff}. ({TKD 3.3.5:src})
▶ {qatlh Dat DI tu'lu', tlhIngan?:sen:nolink} "Why is there rubble everywhere, Klingon?"[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: sway (aircraft moves to the side without yawing)
schwanken (Flugzeug bewegt zur Seite ohne zu neigen)
It is unknown if this has meaning outside of the context of aircraft attitude descriptions.

table.name: mem
table.column: Watch the "A Klingon Christmas Carol" trailer where this is used: {YouTube video:url:http://www.youtube.com/v/5Nc5t9AZYsM}
The term {DawI' yaH:n:nolink} is used for "stage" in Hamlet.
▶ {qatlh tlhIngan lut luja' tera'ngan DawI'pu'lI'?:sen:nolink} "Why are your earthling actors telling a Klingon story?"[1]

table.name: mem
table.column: This is the second highest rank of {QaS:n:1h}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a title for a warrior who has attained legendary status in life.
[1] {DS9 - Blood Oath:src}, [2] {A Good Day to Die:src}, [3] {Saarbrücken qepHom'a' 2014:src}

table.name: mem
table.column: a bird characterized by erratic, unpredictable behavior
Vogel typisch für sein unberechenbares Verhalten
This bird is similar to a {Da'vI':n}.
This is a reference to Donald Duck.

table.name: mem
table.column: a bird characterized by erratic, unpredictable behavior
Vogel typisch für sein unberechenbares Verhalten
This is a reference to Daffy Duck.

table.name: mem
table.column: The object is the thing being surrounded. {-Daq:n:suff} is unnecessary.[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: This can also refer to the suits in a deck of playing cards, for which see {meyrI':n}, {por:n}, {Sor:n}, and {'eSpeD:n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This refers to a duty station on a ship, not to something worn on the head (which would be {mIv:n:1}).

table.name: mem
table.column: For Klingons, this is preferred to {baQ:v:2}.

table.name: mem
table.column: Your face looks like a collapsed star!
Dein Gesicht sieht aus wie ein kollabierter Stern!

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a {no' Hol:n} expression used by a captain upon taking command of a ship.

table.name: mem
table.column:
This word was awarded to {Qov:n:name} as a Friend of Maltz, hence the Canadian spelling in the definition.
In {DSC - The Vulcan Hello:src}, the albino Voq's (see {voq:n:name}) skin colour was described as {Dem:v:nolink}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is also called {DenIbya':n:nolink}, typically by older speakers.[2]
This was defined as "Denebia" in {TKD:src}, but it was later clarified that this was an error and the English name of this planet is actually "Deneb".[3]

table.name: mem
table.column:
This creature is also called {DenIbya' Qatlh:n:nolink}.
Watch Gowron say this: {YouTube video:url:http://www.youtube.com/v/7qXuTn9HpP4}

table.name: mem
table.column: A Denebian is also called a {DenIbya'ngan:n:nolink}.

table.name: mem
table.column: In the Terran retelling of {Hamlet:src}, the titular character is the prince of this country on Earth.

table.name: mem
table.column: She is a member of the House of D'Ghor ({Daghor tuq:n:name}).

table.name: mem
table.column: The suffix for the plural of this word depends on whether it is used to refer to beings capable of using language (see {-pu':n:suff}) or beings incapable of using language (see {-mey:n:suff}).

table.name: mem
table.column: This verb is also used idiomatically, so that for example {Deq SuvwI'@@Deq:v, SuvwI':n} is similar to the English expression "That warrior is history".

table.name: mem
table.column: yaw (aircraft nose points left or right)
It is unknown if this word has meaning outside the context of aircraft attitude.
The rud"der" controls the yaw on an airplane.

table.name: mem
table.column: This word is used for both the body part and the handle of a {nevDagh:n}. Note that the suffix {-Du':n} is used even with the latter meaning.

table.name: mem
table.column: closet, cupboard, cabinet, fixed storage device
This does not necessarily have to be fixed in place.

table.name: mem
table.column: ▶ {juDev 'ej Dujvam ra'wI' DagheS 'e' vItlhob} "I ask you to lead us as commander of this ship", or literally, "I request that you lead us and that you assume the duties of commander of this ship"[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: If you're looking for someone named "Data", see {qoqyoq:n:hyp}.

table.name: mem
table.column: Knowledge of useful information may be unfortunate.
Das Wissen nützlicher Informationen kann nachteilig sein.

table.name: mem
table.column: The name of the author of this program and the compiler of its lexicon.

table.name: mem
table.column: This term is normally used only for fairly big (or powerful) computers.[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: ▶ {qatlh Dat DI tu'lu', tlhIngan?:sen:nolink} "Why is there rubble everywhere, Klingon?"[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: In slang, "(first) dibs" means the right to something.

table.name: mem
table.column: This suffix turns a cardinal number into an ordinal number. For example, {wa'DIch:n:num} "first" from {wa':n:num} "one", {cha'DIch:n:1,num} "second" from {cha':n:num} "two", and so on. Ordinal numbers follow the noun to which they apply.

table.name: mem
table.column: ▶ {DaH nuq wIDIgh:sen:nolink} "What do we undertake now?"

table.name: mem
table.column: Its leaf ({DIghna' por:n:nolink}) is fried (see {mIQ:v}) by experienced cooks.[1, p.94]

table.name: mem
table.column: This is deep-fried (see {mIQ:v}) and eaten.[1, p.94]

table.name: mem
table.column: Attack or be slaves in their world!
Wir werden Sklaven in ihrer Welt, wenn wir sie nicht angreifen.

table.name: mem
table.column: Attack them now, while we still can!
Wir müssen sie jetzt angreifen, solange wir sie angreifen können!

table.name: mem
table.column: slide sword blade along opponent's blade

table.name: mem
table.column: use a pigment stick, paint with pigment stick

table.name: mem
mem
table.column: This word is not defined as such in canon, but appears in the example from {TKD p.171:src}. This entry is here for ease of reference only.
▶ {Dochvetlh DIlmeH Huch 'ar DaneH?:sen} "How much do you want for that?"[1]

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a traded commodity, like {qevaS:n}.
There is a genus of Terran flowering plants called the trillium. However, it seems that this word may actually refer to a mineral or perhaps a type of gemstone, although this is unclear.

table.name: mem
table.column: open entryway (to corridor, tunnel, conduit, Jeffries tube, branch of sewer)
offener Durchgang (zu Korridor, Tunnel, Rohrleitung, Jeffriesröhre, Kanalisation usw.
This is the open entryway of any enclosed space longer than wide in which people might find themselves. If there is a door that closes, this is not a {DIn:n:nolink}. It is merely a {lojmIt:n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: MO implied at {Saarbrücken qepHom'a' 2011:src} that {DIng:v:nolink} is intransitive by saying that it works in the same way as {jIr:v:nolink}, but did not elaborate on the exact difference between the two verbs.

table.name: mem
mem
table.column: This word takes the suffix {-Du':n:suff} when it refers to skin still on the body, and {-mey:n:suff} otherwise.[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: When the context is clear, this is sometimes shortened to {DIr bID:n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is the name of a specific skin disease from the time of Kahless.

table.name: mem
table.column: This can refer to one pattern/design, or to a whole lot of them taken together.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a drum made with animal skin stretched over a cylinder, usually over only one end. If skin is stretched over both ends of a drum, it is an {'o'lav:n}.[1]

table.name: mem
table.column: For "years ago" and "years from now", see {ben:n:1} and {nem:n}, respectively.

table.name: mem
table.column: To "dish (out)" is slang for giving away information.

table.name: mem
table.column: There is no traditional Klingon way to say "Happy New Year", though a Klingon might understand {DIS chu' yItIv@@DIS:n:2, chu':v:1, yI-:v, tIv:v} or {DIS chu' DatIvjaj@@DIS:n:2, chu':v:1, Da-:v, tIv:v, -jaj:v} or {DIS chu' botIvjaj@@DIS:n:2, chu':v:1, bo-:v, tIv:v, -jaj:v}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is the name of a Federation starship.

table.name: mem
table.column:
This word is used to refer to "the Federation", a shortened form of "the United Federation of Planets" ({yuQjIjDIvI':n}).
Coincidentally or not, this words sounds similar to {DI vI':n:nolink} "it accumulates debris".
The real reason {DIvI':n:nolink} and {DI vI':n:nolink} sound alike is because of the backfitting of {vaj toDuj Daj ngeHbej DI vI'.:sen}

table.name: mem
table.column: DIvI' Se' wI'IjtaHvIS DaH ngoqDe' wIHevta'.
We've just received an encoded message on the Federation frequency.
Wir haben jetzt eine verschlüsselte Nachricht auf der Föderationsfrequenz empfangen.
This line was cut from {Star Trek V:src}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This can be used for "personality" in the sense of a quality or trait that forms a person's character.[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: ▶ {DI'ruj velqa' nIqHom:n@@DI'ruj velqa':n, nIqHom:n} "virtual reality software"

table.name: mem
table.column: This term does not appear in canon. This entry is here for ease of reference only.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a {Qe':n} with a sign that says {moD Soj:sen:nolink}.[1, p.102]

table.name: mem
table.column: This is not canonical but is apparently widely known, after the model of {Do Qe':n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: How much do you want for that?

table.name: mem
table.column: This refers to the separator used in specifying a set of coordinates, and not to a specific coordinate point or location (for which see {Quv:n}).
▶ {He wej pagh Soch DoD cha':sen:nolink} "course 3-0-7-mark-2"[2] ▶ {He pagh-pagh-pagh-DoD-cha' yInab!:sen}

table.name: mem
table.column: There is an idiom {Dogh; tIghla' rur:sen@@Dogh:v, tIghla':n, rur:v}.[2, p.127]

table.name: mem
table.column: This consists of the words for "silly" and "defeat".

table.name: mem
table.column: back away from, back off, get away from
sich von etw. entfernen, rückwärts gehen, weggehen
▶ {noH QapmeH wo' Qaw'lu'chugh yay chavbe'lu' 'ej wo' choqmeH may' DoHlu'chugh lujbe'lu'.:sen}[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: Based on the example of {qawmoH:v}, the subject of {DoHmoH:v:nolink} does the driving back, {-vaD:n} marks that which is driven back, and the object is the thing or location it is driven back from.
This is defined in the body of {KGT:src} on p.48.

table.name: mem
table.column: This word can refer to people or otherwise. Even if referring only to beings capable of using language, one would normally not say {Dojpu':n:nolink}.

table.name: mem
table.column: mass, masses, multitude, a very large but indeterminate group of something
Massen, Mengen, eine große aber unbekannte Anzahl von Gegenständen oder Personen
This word can refer to people or otherwise. Even if referring only to beings capable of using language, one would normally not say {Dojpu':n:nolink}.
The example sentence is a lip-match for {'ej DochmeywIj vItlhapqa'meH}.
▶ {'ej Dojmey wID, vInDa'ma' peq.} "He has killed many of our people." ▶ {qoq De'wI' Dojmey:n}

table.name: mem
table.column: This is defined as "entity" in {TKD:src} and as "whole" in {TKW:src}.

table.name: mem
table.column: To say that two or more things are parallel, this verb is used with a plural subject.[2]
The "go parallel to" definition suggests that this verb can be used transitively. However, the noun {HeDon} also suggests that {Don} acts like a verb of quality.

table.name: mem
table.column: In {Klingon Monopoly:src}, {Dop:n:nolink} is used to indicate one face of a playing card.
▶ {DopDaq qul yIchenmoH QobDI' ghu'.:sen}[2] ▶ {'echletHom Dopvam yIcha':sen:nolink} "card must be turned this side up"[3]

table.name: mem
table.column: Set fire on the side when there is danger.
Stell das Feuer beiseite wenn Gefahr droht.

table.name: mem
table.column: This verb also covers colors which would be called "brown". To differentiate a brown object from another object which could also be described using {Doq:v:nolink}, a phrase such as {Doq 'ej wovbe':sen} is used.[2]

All natural languages found on Earth divide colours into "warm" and "cool" in the same way. Klingon distinguishes between {Doq:v:nolink} and {SuD:v:1}, but it groups "yellow" with the "cool" colours rather than with the "warm" colours.

table.name: mem
table.column: The expressions {Doq bIQtIq:sen:nolink} ("the river is red") and {Doq bIQtIq bIQ:sen:nolink} ("the river water is red") can be traced back to an old drinking song commemorating the slaying of {molor:n:name} by {qeylIS'e' lIjlaHbe'bogh vay':n:name}.

table.name: mem
table.column: to be a particular shade of brown
Doq und wie Kradsch-Lippen (ein bräunlicher Ton)
A kradge has brown lips. This expression is used to describe an object which is a particular shade of brown (see {Doq 'ej wovbe':sen}).

table.name: mem
table.column: To be more specific about the shade of brown, a comparison is used. For example, one might say {Doq 'ej Qaj wuS rur:sen} (kradge lips are a particular shade of brown).[1]

table.name: mem
mem
mem
table.column: sink for cleaning hands, face, food, etc.
Becken, Spüle, z.B. in Küche oder Bad

A bathtub or swimming pool would be a {DoQmIv'a':n@@DoQmIv:n, -'a':n}. When needed, these can be distinguished using qualifiers: {Say'moHmeH DoQmIv'a':n}, {QalmeH DoQmIv'a':n}. A {DoQmIvHom:n@@DoQmIv:n, -Hom:n} would be a bucket or anything similar.

table.name: mem
table.column: The subject of this verb is a period or unit of time, such as a month. It should not be an event the ending of which one has some control over (for which see {van:v:2}, {ghang:v}).
▶ {tugh Dor qoSlIj. nom yIlop!@@tugh:adv, Dor:v:2, qoS:n, -lIj:n, nom:adv, yI-:v, lop:v}[2]

table.name: mem
mem
table.column: This idiomatic expression, which literally means to lose or misplace a target, means "to digress". {DoS vIchIl:sen:nolink} means "I digress", and so on.

table.name: mem
table.column: We have a target in sight.
Wir haben ein Ziel in Sicht.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is generally crafted from bone.

table.name: mem
table.column: It is unclear if {tlhuch:v} "exhaust" means to "tire someone out".

table.name: mem
table.column: This is essentially the verb {Do'Ha':v} as a standalone sentence.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is the name of a planet which was disputed between the United Federation of Planets ({yuQjIjDIvI':n}) and the Klingon Empire ({tlhIngan wo':n}).

table.name: mem
table.column:
The object is the thing which is improved.
This verb is used for improvement of a more abstract nature, such as in status, skill, understanding, etc. For improvement in a more concrete sense, see {rach:v}.[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: If it's in your way, knock it down.
Wenn dir etwas im Wege steht, schlag es nieder.

table.name: mem
table.column: As a joke, this is missing from the E-K side of {TKD:src}.

table.name: mem
table.column: ▶ {yIntaHvIS qIrq DuHbe' roj.:sen:nolink} "There will be no peace as long as Kirk lives." ({Star Trek V:src} notes, not actually in the film)

table.name: mem
table.column:
This word can refer to any vehicle, not just spaceships, by specifying the environment in which the vehicle travels. See {puH Duj:n}, {muD Duj:n}, {bIQ Duj:n}.
Some special terminology is used for the parts of a {Duj:n:1h,nolink}. The section towards its {tlhop:n:1h} is called its {'et:n:2h}, while the section towards its {'em:n} is called its {'o':n}. To refer to a ship's dorsal, ventral, port, and starboard areas, see {Dung:n}, {bIng:n}, {poS:n}, and {nIH:n}, respectively.
For verbs related to ship movement, see under {'or:v}.
Known classes of Klingon ships include {neghvar:n}, {vorcha':n}, {qItI'nga':n}, {qISa'ruj:n}, and {toQDuj:n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: It is grammatically correct to treat this word as singular (a bundle of instincts) or plural (individual instincts).[2, p.27]

table.name: mem
table.column: DujDaj HubtaHvIS Hegh 'e' tul Hoch tlhIngan.
To die defending his ship is the hope of every Klingon.
Es ist die Hoffnung jedes Klingon zu sterben während er sein Schiff verteidigt.

table.name: mem
table.column: There is nothing shameful in falling before a superior enemy.
Es ist nicht schmachvoll vor einem überlegenen Feind zu verlieren.

table.name: mem
table.column: ▶ {Dujmey law' DachIjpu':sen:nolink} "You have navigated many ships", i.e., "You are experienced".

table.name: mem
table.column: This refers to the geometric figure, and not to an astronomical body, for which see {Hov:n}.

This seems to be made up of the words {Duj:n:1} and {tlhuQ:n}.
The logo of Star Alliance, the largest airline alliance on Earth, is often painted on the tailfins of its members' airplanes.

table.name: mem
table.column: ▶ {ta'mey Dun, bommey Dun.:sen} ▶ {qIbDaq SuvwI''e' SoH Dun law' Hoch Dun puS.:sen}

table.name: mem
table.column: See {'aqroS:n:1} and {yor:n} for the top parts of an object. See also {lurgh:n} for other words related to spatial directions.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a way to "dupe" your enemies.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a bowl used for eating {chatlh:n:1}, which a diner pours into the {Duq:n:nolink} from a {maHpIn:n}.[1, p.99]
Norm Duke is the name of a successful American professional bowler. Also, "duckpin bowling" is a variation of "ten-pin bowling" using a smaller ball.

table.name: mem
table.column: This means in the sense of astonished, astounded, dumbfounded, shocked. It is stronger than {yay':v}
Dies ist im sinne von erstaunt, umgeworfen, schockiert. Es ist stärker als {yay':v}

table.name: mem
table.column: This is said of good music or food.

table.name: mem
table.column:
This is used to refer to the spikes attached to {pogh:n}, {ghanjaq:n}, {'alngegh:n}, and so on.
For a stand-alone spike such as a stake, see {wIl:n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is used to refer to the little spikes found on the {Daqtagh:n}.[1, p.61]

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a food item. It never uses any plural suffix.

table.name: mem
table.column:
This is used for launching a {peng:n}.
The distinction between a {DuS:n:nolink} and a {chetvI':n} has to do with how the projectile is loaded.[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: This is the most general word for a place of learning.[1]
It's probably just a coincidence that this word looks like it's formed from {Du-:v} and {SaQ:v}.

table.name: mem
table.column: ▶ {toqwIn vIDut@@toqwIn:n, vI-:v, Dut:v} "I slam down the stamp."

table.name: mem
table.column: This refers to fruits or vegetables that come from a farm, as opposed to {naH tlhab:n}.[1, p.89]

table.name: mem
table.column: There is a typo in this sentence in {TKD:src}, an extra space right after {mIv:n:1}.
